title: My Social Life With Sickle Cell Disease: Why Iâ€™m Calm, Cool and Collected

content: I do my best not to let sickle cell impact my social life, but it does influence how I interact with the world. I must look within to understand how sickle cell disease affects my social life. What is my personality, and how do others perceive me? Reserved, calm, and quiet are adjectives that have been used to describe myself at some point, and they're accurate. I usually step out of my shell only when I'm around people I'm comfortable with or in a one-on-one situation. I am more reserved in group settings and take a back seat to others.

It's understandable why people would describe me this way. I can think of countless examples when I've displayed these characteristics. However, I've always wondered how much of it is because of who I am and how much is due to my chronic condition. Physical, emotional, and mental stress all negatively impact my body. The impact of these stresses influences how I manage my life with sickle cell disease and how I interact with others.

content: I've mentioned before how a young version of me believed that excitement always leads to pain. This trauma meant that I always tried to contain my excitement to prevent a sickle cell crisis. The young kid jumping around at exciting news grew up to be an adult who would wait until an event happened before showing any excitement.

As an adult, I'm learning to vocalize my excitement more, even if what I physically display on the outside is often nonchalant, which can be perceived as passive or as not caring about what's happening around me. I care; I am very accustomed to keeping my emotions in check. In adulthood, I've discovered more things I'm passionate about and responsibilities that push me out of my comfort zone. These passions have helped me go back against the limits I had placed on my excitement.

I tend to be calm about things because I have strong emotions. This statement sounds like a contradiction. However, I am a tranquil person and it's difficult for me to appear overwhelmed or stressed because neither of these emotions is beneficial when managing sickle cell disease. I can feel my body responding negatively when I have strong negative emotions.

content: Of course, it's impossible to never be overwhelmed or stressed. Growing up, I didn't healthily manage these situations, so my emotions would always build to explosive levels, which often would lead to a crisis. Now, I'm learning to process these emotions healthily to avoid the potential repercussions for my health.

I am soft-spoken, sometimes annoyingly so. As a result, I'm often asked to repeat things and project my voice more. I always thought that this is just how I am, but I regress even further after a crisis. It takes a lot of energy to project my voice and be loud, so it is part of the emotional defense mechanism I've developed to maintain a calm status quo.

Thankfully, I am more conscious and do my best to speak up. As an advocate, mentor, and leader, being soft-spoken is always impossible. Using these roles to help pull me out of my quietness has allowed me to be more open and share my personality.

content: Being reserved, calm, and quiet are aspects of my personality. It's undeniable that my chronic condition has played a part in this. However, I can be different at this stage in my life, as I am more aware of how my chronic illness affects me. I can continue to push the emotional limits I have placed on myself due to pain.

Embracing all these parts of me will allow my true personality to shine through when I am not in pain. This is why I cherish the moments when I can do something I love pain-free. I value new experiences greatly, such as exploring new places, meeting new people, trying new foods, etc. Each experience is embedded in my mind to remind me that I have lived and continue to do so.

As I grow older, I want positive memories, not negative ones, to take precedence in my life. I don't want to reflect on my life and think only about sickle cell and pain. I don't want to think about what sickle cell has taken from me or impacted me. Instead, I want to look back at my life memories because I learned to come out of my shell.
